close_symbols: All code/sites that initialize or assign session->value_1 and session->value_2
Any macros/constants that bound value_1/value_2 storage (e.g. VALUE_1_MAX_LEN, VALUE_2_MAX_LEN) or allocation sizes
explanation:
You must be able to determine whether the strlen/snprintf calls in fill_v1_v2_form can read or write out of bounds. Concretely:

- SECOND_PAGE: The exact content of this format string is required. If it contains format specifiers (e.g. %s, %.*s, width/precision modifiers, %n, etc.) they affect the length of the formatted result and how many/what types of arguments are consumed. To check that the computed slen and the snprintf(slen+1, ...) allocation are correct (and that no extra or mismatched format specifiers cause undefined behaviour), analyze the literal/macro SECOND_PAGE.

- struct Session (definition): You need the type of session->value_1 and session->value_2 (char * vs char[] vs other), and whether they are guaranteed to be null-terminated strings. strlen() requires a valid pointer to a NUL-terminated object; if the members are not char* or can be NULL/unterminated, the strlen calls would violate the rule.

- All code/sites that initialize or assign session->value_1 and session->value_2: Knowing how these fields are set (where they come from, allocation routines, possible values) is necessary to determine whether they can be NULL, not NUL-terminated, or longer than any assumed bound. This affects both the strlen calls and the arithmetic slen = strlen(...) + ... (overflow or unterminated reads).

- Any macros/constants that bound value_1/value_2 storage (e.g. VALUE_1_MAX_LEN, VALUE_2_MAX_LEN) or allocation sizes: To prove the arithmetic that computes slen cannot overflow size_t and that malloc(slen+1) provides sufficient space, you need any compile-time or run-time limits on those strings (fixed array sizes, guaranteed max lengths).

These symbols let you decide (1) whether the pointers passed to strlen are valid and point to NUL-terminated objects (MISRA concern), (2) whether the computed slen correctly bounds the formatted output written by snprintf (no buffer overflow), and (3) whether any integer overflow can occur during the length computation.
